author: Phil McKnight
title: Promptous Dental MetaData
description: Data on the utilization of dental procedures is primarily produced and held by carriers, meaning it is not used to benefit patients

assessments.note: There is no real detail as to what this proposal has to do with metadata on the blockchain. Whilst it may be an interesting use case, the details of the proposal need to be fleshed out.

The proposal is aiming to develop a costing model based on using industry and company-specific metadata. The details of the type and manner in which the data is currently existing will help in the assessment of the effectiveness. How will this model be released for community befit is also not clear from the proposal.

the problem statement doesn't have enough detail to grasp how large the problem is, who it is a problem for, or why it matters. In addition, it isn't clear why this needs to be in Metadata of a transaction. Why Couldn't this data be shared through an open API instead?

This proposal is really short and except for the website there is not much content. It is hard to tell if this is acually an issue because of a missing detailed description of an actuall proplem. It kinda reminds me of Dentacoin which is considered a failed project. The proposal doesn't really show how a blockchain is going to solve this and how it is goning to benefit our community.

The proposal does not mention using Cardano transaction metadata, but that is the core requirement for the Metadata Challenge. (Its mention of "company-specific metadata" is not related/connected to Cardano transaction metadata.)

Draft proposal. The description of the problem and solution are within the scope of the challenge, patient records are data that can be recorded with the help of metadata, but the absence of a detailed rationale and plan makes it impossible to assess the potential impact on this challenge.

Whilst the proposer may have the experience to produce the project, there are not detail on what it is actually going to produce and thus it is hard to determine if it would be likely to be successfully implemented
The proposer is involved in a dental insurance space therefore there is a very good chance that they will be capable of completing the project.

While there is plenty of experience in the insurance field an unknown amount of blockchain experience is presented. It is also unclear how the proposer would convince carriers to share this data, or how the data would be provided to the chain in a trustless manner.

In my opinion ''Blockchain''-Experience doesn't really show the voter what kind of experience the Team has. The team didn't introduce themselves. The proposal doesn't ask for a lot of funds. But it is not clear for what the funds are used for. If it was a serious Insurance-Protocoll the requested funds should be higher to succeed.

The proposal does not describe a plan to utilize the metadata capabilities of the UTxO model--"development of a actuarial model" does not constitute such a plan--, nor does it state that the proposers have Cardano-specific experience.

Draft proposal. There is no information about the plan and this prevents assessing whether the team is able to implement the proposal. The team has experience in the dental insurance market, but there is no information about technical experience for the development of an application/software.

I recommend that the team submit a proposal with details so that we can give appropriate feedback and assess the feasibility.

The proposal needs to bring out the type and current source for data to be put on the blockchain. However, the proposal is to develop the model to estimate the cost based on "off-chain " metadata. Therefore the effectiveness of the proposal in exploiting the Metadata feature of Cardano is not clear.
Given that the proposal fails to share what metrics support the problem statement, it is extremely difficult to judge success of the proposal.

The proposal is too short to properly assess it. There is unfortunately no roadmap and no Clear understandable description of problem and solution. I would recommend to re-write your proposal so the community sees clearly what you're trying to achieve and then re-submit for the next fund.
The proposal does not include a timeline, measurable/quantifiable metrics, or any specific deliverables.

Draft proposal. There is no information on auditability.

I recommend that the team follow the Catalyst documentation to detail the proposal.

solution: Development of a actuarial model using industry and company-specific metadata in order to better communicate dental costs to patients
experience:
Founded Insurtech startup Promptous provding benefits to employers

Blockchain experience

20+ years collective experience in insurance
